DOC.HEAD: East, West Germany Begin Exchanging Spies
Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with major spy exchanges already occurring; picks up 5th graf pvs, `East German...'
DOC.TEXT: East Germany and West Germany have begun a major exchange of convicted spies, government security officials said Wednesday. The officials, who spoke on condition of anomyity, said East Germany has begun releasing about 25 imprisoned Westerners, some of whom were serving life sentences. West Germany will release four former Communist agents in return, they said. The four include two top catches of West German counterintelligence efforts: Margret Hoeke, an ex-secretary to West Germany's president, and Elke Falk, a former secretary in the chancellor's offices. Pardons for the two women were announced earlier in the day by a spokesman for West German President Richard von Weizsaecker. The spokesman, Gernot Fritz, said he did not know if they had been released from prison. The two women have said, however, that they don't want to be handed over to East Germany and they won't be forced to leave West Germany, security officials said. Officials did not release the names of any other agents being released. East German Premier Hans Modrow and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl met in Dresden, East Germany, on Tuesday and said there were plans to release as many political prisoners as possible before Christmas. Ms. Hoeke was convicted in 1987 of spying for East Germany and sentenced to eight years in prison. She had worked in the offices of several West German presidents, including Weizsaecker, before her arrest in August 1985. Ms. Falk, was convicted of spying for the Soviet KGB in 1989 and sentenced to 6{ years in prison. She had worked as a secretary in the offices of the chancellor, the transport ministry and economic cooperation ministry before her arrest in 1988.
